subject: Re: [junit] JUnit4TestAdapter and its documentation
msgSnippet: Hello Anna, I hope the example bellow can match your needs: package foo; import org.junit.runner.JUnitCore; import org.junit.runner.RunWith; import
messageBody:
Hello Anna,

I hope the example bellow can match your needs:

package foo;

import org.junit.runner.JUnitCore;
import org.junit.runner.RunWith;
import org.junit.runners.Suite;
import org.junit.runners.Suite.SuiteClasses;

@RunWith(Suite.class)
@SuiteClasses( { SampleTest.class, AnotherTest.class, foo.bar.AllTests.class})
public class AllTests {
public static void main(String[] args) {
JUnitCore.main(AllTests.class.getName());
}
}

Regards,
Tiago

On 4/18/06, elfeczka <elfeczka@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> I've just only started with JUnit, so forgive me if my problems are
> irrelevant.
>
> I'm trying to use JUnit4.0 while working with Eclipse 3.1, so I needed
> to get acquainted with JUnit4TestAdapter.
>
> What I wanted to achieve was creating several test suites inside a
> package that would perform different test methods from one test class.
> That's at least how I understood the idea of organising tests :/
>
> I expected to find some methods similar to TestSuite.addTestSuite() in
> the JUnit4TestAdapter class, still, the only way to create a test
> suite with its help that seems to exist is the FAQ-one:
>
> public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
> return new junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter(SimpleTest.class);
> }
>
> 1. Is it nonsense what I was trying to achieve?
> 2. Why is there no documentation on JUnit4TestAdapter in JUnit's Javadoc?
> 3. Can I manually add particular test methods to the Adapter object?
> 4. Are there any samples showing how to use the @RunWith and
> @SuiteClasses annottations? (I guess I'm too dumb to get it having
> read Javadoc, and google just won't do).
>
> Thanks,
>
> Anna Skawinska
